elementsÂ¶

This module includes elemental data taken from 1 and 2, and functions to calculate molecular properties from elemental data.

References

1(1,2)

N M OâBoyle, M Banck, C A James, C Morley, T Vandermeersch, and G R Hutchison. âOpen Babel: An open chemical toolbox.â J. Cheminf. (2011), 3, 33. DOI:10.1186/1758-2946-3-33

2

RDKit: Open-source cheminformatics; http://www.rdkit.org

3

LaÅ¡tovka, VÃ¡clav, Nasser Sallamie, and John M. Shaw. âA Similarity Variable for Estimating the Heat Capacity of Solid Organic Compounds: Part I. Fundamentals.â Fluid Phase Equilibria 268, no. 1-2 (June 25, 2008): 51-60. doi:10.1016/j.fluid.2008.03.019.

4

Hill, Edwin A.ââON A SYSTEM OF INDEXING CHEMICAL LITERATURE; ADOPTED BY THE CLASSIFICATION DIVISION OF THE U. S. PATENT OFFICE.1.â Journal of the American Chemical Society 22, no. 8 (August 1, 1900): 478-94. doi:10.1021/ja02046a005.

class thermosteam.properties.elements.PeriodicTable(elements)[source]Â¶

Periodic Table object for use in dealing with elements.

Parameters

elements (Iterable[Element]) â List of Element objects

Notes

Has a length of 118 elements.

See also

periodic_table, Element

thermosteam.properties.elements.compute_molecular_weight(atoms)[source]Â¶

Return molecular weight of a molecule given a dictionary of its atoms and their counts, in the format {symbol: count}.

\[MW = \sum_i n_i MW_i\]
Parameters

atoms (dict) â dictionary of counts of individual atoms, indexed by symbol with proper capitalization, [-]

Returns

MW â Calculated molecular weight [g/mol]

Return type

float

Notes

Elemental data is from rdkit, with CAS numbers added. An exception is raised if an incorrect element symbol is given. Elements up to 118 are supported, as are deutreium and tritium.

Examples

>>> compute_molecular_weight({'H': 12, 'C': 20, 'O': 5}) # DNA
332.30628
thermosteam.properties.elements.compute_mass_fractions(atoms, MW=None)[source]Â¶

Return the mass fractions of each element in a compound, given a dictionary of its atoms and their counts, in the format {symbol: count}.

\[w_i = \frac{n_i MW_i}{\sum_i n_i MW_i}\]
Parameters

  • atoms (dict) â dictionary of counts of individual atoms, indexed by symbol with proper capitalization, [-]

  • MW (float, optional) â Molecular weight, [g/mol]

Returns

mfracs â dictionary of mass fractions of individual atoms, indexed by symbol with proper capitalization, [-]

Return type

dict

Notes

Molecular weight is optional, but speeds up the calculation slightly. It is calculated using the function compute_molecular_weight if not specified.

Elemental data is from rdkit, with CAS numbers added. An exception is raised if an incorrect element symbol is given. Elements up to 118 are supported.

Examples

>>> compute_mass_fractions({'H': 12, 'C': 20, 'O': 5})
{'H': 0.03639798802478244, 'C': 0.7228692758981262, 'O': 0.24073273607709128}
thermosteam.properties.elements.compute_atom_fractions(atoms)[source]Â¶

Return the atomic fractions of each element in a compound, given a dictionary of its atoms and their counts, in the format {symbol: count}.

\[a_i = \frac{n_i}{\sum_i n_i}\]
Parameters

atoms (dict) â dictionary of counts of individual atoms, indexed by symbol with proper capitalization, [-]

Returns

afracs â dictionary of atomic fractions of individual atoms, indexed by symbol with proper capitalization, [-]

Return type

dict

Notes

No actual data on the elements is used, so incorrect or custom compounds would not raise an error.

Examples

>>> compute_atom_fractions({'H': 12, 'C': 20, 'O': 5})
{'H': 0.32432432432432434, 'C': 0.5405405405405406, 'O': 0.13513513513513514}
thermosteam.properties.elements.compute_similarity_variable(atoms, MW=None)[source]Â¶

Return the similarity variable of an compound, as defined in 3. Currently only applied for certain heat capacity estimation routines.

\[\alpha = \frac{N}{MW} = \frac{\sum_i n_i}{\sum_i n_i MW_i}\]
Parameters

  • atoms (dict) â dictionary of counts of individual atoms, indexed by symbol with proper capitalization, [-]

  • MW (float, optional) â Molecular weight, [g/mol]

Returns

compute_similarity_variable â Similarity variable as defined in 1, [mol/g]

Return type

float

Notes

Molecular weight is optional, but speeds up the calculation slightly. It is calculated using the function compute_molecular_weight if not specified.

Examples

>>> compute_similarity_variable({'H': 32, 'C': 15})
0.2212654140784498
thermosteam.properties.elements.atoms_to_Hill(atoms)[source]Â¶

Determine the Hill formula of a compound as in 4, given a dictionary of its atoms and their counts, in the format {symbol: count}.

Parameters

atoms (dict) â dictionary of counts of individual atoms, indexed by symbol with proper capitalization, [-]

Returns

Hill_formula â Hill formula, [-]

Return type

str

Notes

The Hill system is as follows:

If the chemical has âCâ in it, this is listed first, and then if it has âHâ in it as well as âCâ, then that goes next. All elements are sorted alphabetically afterwards, including âHâ if âCâ is not present. All elements are followed by their count, unless it is 1.

Examples

>>> atoms_to_Hill({'H': 5, 'C': 2, 'Br': 1})
'C2H5Br'
thermosteam.properties.elements.parse_simple_formula(formula)[source]Â¶

Basic formula parser, primarily for obtaining element counts from formulas as formated in PubChem. Handles formulas with integer counts, but no brackets, no hydrates, no charges, no isotopes, and no group multipliers.

Strips charges from the end of a formula first. Accepts repeated chemical units. Performs no sanity checking that elements are actually elements. As it uses regular expressions for matching, errors are mostly just ignored.

Parameters

formula (str) â Formula string, very simply formats only.

Returns

atoms â dictionary of counts of individual atoms, indexed by symbol with proper capitalization, [-]

Return type

dict

Notes

Inspiration taken from the thermopyl project, at https://github.com/choderalab/thermopyl.

Examples

>>> parse_simple_formula('CO2')
{'C': 1, 'O': 2}
thermosteam.properties.elements.parse_nested_formula(formula, check=True)[source]Â¶

Improved formula parser which handles braces and their multipliers, as well as rational element counts.

Strips charges from the end of a formula first. Accepts repeated chemical units. Performs no sanity checking that elements are actually elements. As it uses regular expressions for matching, errors are mostly just ignored.

Parameters

  • formula (str) â Formula string, very simply formats only.

  • check (bool) â If check is True, a simple check will be performed to determine if a formula is not a formula and an exception will be raised if it is not, [-]

Returns

atoms â dictionary of counts of individual atoms, indexed by symbol with proper capitalization, [-]

Return type

dict

Notes

Inspired by the approach taken by CrazyMerlyn on a reddit DailyProgrammer challenge, at https://www.reddit.com/r/dailyprogrammer/comments/6eerfk/20170531_challenge_317_intermediate_counting/

Examples

>>> pprint(parse_nested_formula('Pd(NH3)4.0001+2'))
{'H': 12.0003, 'N': 4.0001, 'Pd': 1}
thermosteam.properties.elements.charge_from_formula(formula)[source]Â¶

Basic formula parser to determine the charge from a formula - given that the charge is already specified as one element of the formula.

Performs no sanity checking that elements are actually elements.

Parameters

formula (str) â Formula string, very simply formats only, ending in one of â+xâ, â-xâ, n*â+â, or n*â-â or any of them surrounded by brackets but always at the end of a formula.

Returns

charge â Charge of the molecule, [faraday]

Return type

int

Notes

Examples

>>> charge_from_formula('Br3-')
-1
>>> charge_from_formula('Br3(-)')
-1
thermosteam.properties.elements.serialize_formula(formula)[source]Â¶

Basic formula serializer to construct a consistently-formatted formula. This is necessary for handling user-supplied formulas, which are not always well formatted.

Performs no sanity checking that elements are actually elements.

Parameters

formula (str) â Formula string as parseable by the method parse_nested_formula, [-]

Returns

formula â A consistently formatted formula to describe a molecular formula, [-]

Return type

str

Examples

>>> serialize_formula('Pd(NH3)4+3')
'H12N4Pd+3'
